collection.title: Javi Frias - Red Bull Mix
collection.description:
http://www.redbull.com/es/es/music/stories/1331766193751/viernes-de-mix-javi-frias

El DJ y productor Javi Fr√≠as lleva m√°s de 15 a√±os agitando la capital con sus sesiones de soul, funk, disco, boogie y house. Un habitual de sitios como el Caf√© Berl√≠n, Tempo Club, Populart Club, Siroco, El Junco o El Intruso. Ha recorrido tambi√©n las cabinas de los mejores clubs de m√∫sica negra de toda la pen√≠nsula y parte de Europa y ha sido DJ residente en Afrodisia y Boogaclub en Granada y ha participado en festivales como el Baltic Soul Weekender (Alemania), Contre-Temps (Francia), Heineken Jazzaldia, Cultura Inquieta o Im√°gina Funk. 

Con este currr√≠culo no es de extra√±ar que haya empezando a llamar la atenci√≥n de sellos como Street Edits, Hotbox Boogie o Spa In Disco, donde ha publicado varios EPs, con sus edits y reworks. Ahora acaba de publicar su primer 12", 'Disco Edits Vol. 1', editado en vinilo por el sello Street Edits, propiedad del DJ y productor de Chicago Rahaan, y que est√° teniendo una gran repercusi√≥n dentro de la escena Disco-Edits. Y tambi√©n ha visto la luz 'Shining Bright EP', que se ha publicado en formato digital a trav√©s de sello Hotbox Boogie. Incansable siempre, para el a√±o que viene tambi√©n tiene previsto publicar diferentes edits en varios sellos. Stay tuned!

collection.name: MINIMAL TECHNO

tracks.title: 99% Invisible-87- I Heart NY, TM
tracks.description:
By now, the story is well known. A man sits in the backseat of a cab, sketching on a notepad as night falls over a crumbling city. He scribbles the letter I. He draws a heart. And then an N, and then a Y. Right away he knows he's got something. This is it, he thinks. This is the campaign.

The man was a designer named Milton Glaser. The City was New York. The year was 1977.

The city needed a miracle. And it kind of got one in three letters and a symbol: I ‚ô• NY

The I ‚ô• NY campaign was so successful that it became part of the built environment. So people started doing with I ‚ô• NY the same thing that humans have always done when encountering something in nature: they started imitating it.

tracks.tag_list: hiroshima nagasaki nuclear bomb atomic Radiolab "Jad Abumrad" "Robert Krulwich"
tracks.title: Shorts: Double Blasted
tracks.description: In early August of 1945, Tsutomu Yamaguchi had a run of the worst luck imaginable. A double blast of radiation left his future, and the future of his descendants, in doubt. In this short: an utterly amazing survival story that spans ... well, 4 billion years when you get down to it.

tracks.tag_list: Radiolab "Jad Abumrad" "Robert Krulwich" "Oliver Sacks" memory forgetting
tracks.title: Memory and Forgetting
tracks.description: This hour of Radiolab, a look behind the curtain of how memories are made...and forgotten. Remembering is an unstable and profoundly unreliable process--it‚Äôs easy come, easy go as we learn how true memories can be obliterated, and false ones added. And Oliver Sacks joins us to tell the story of an amnesiac whose love for his wife and music transcend his 7-second memory.

tracks.title: Ep 1:  Animal Instincts
tracks.description: In 2001, a woman was found dead in a pool of her own blood. Her husband was convicted of her murder. But a curious neighbor had a different theory‚Ä¶ one that brings new meaning to man vs. beast.

tracks.title: a16z Podcast: Where the Growth in Cloud and Enterprise Software Really Is (with Marc Benioff)
tracks.description: VCs wouldn't fund Salesforce ("that obviously won't work") when Marc Benioff began. With the cloud a growing part of practically every company, government, organization, and people's lives, a lot's changed since 1999.  But what's next? Do enterprise CEOs get (mobile) religion? [Answer: not yet. Benioff thinks there's a ton of opportunity ahead there.] What's happening with international growth, when countries want their own clouds and 90% of enterprise software is bought in just 7 countries?

tracks.tag_list: UCL Rickman Godlee Lecture 2011 Noam Chomsky global order world politics international domination stability changing
tracks.title: Professor Noam Chomsky - UCL Rickman Godlee Lecture 2011 (Part 2 of 3)
tracks.description:
Professor Noam Chomsky, UCL Rickman Godlee Lecture 2011 (Part 2 of 3)

Contours of global order: Domination, stability, security in a changing world.

Professor Noam Chomsky explores the crucial role of a supportive intellectual culture in an environment of potentially dangerous irrationality in policy-making circles and among sectors of the political class, while institutional structures bar efforts to confront very serious domestic and international issues.

UCLTV Playlist of lecture excerpts: http://bit.ly/dKk2qY

Further links:
Blog post on the event: http://bit.ly/hwklig 
Professor Chomsky's MIT page: http://bit.ly/gon5cT

Part 3 of Lecture:  http://soundcloud.com/uclsound/professor-noam-chomsky-ucl-2

UCL is consistently ranked as one of the world's top universities. Across all disciplines our faculties are known for their research-intensive approaches, academic excellence and engagement with global challenges. This is the basis of our world-renowned degree programmes. Visit us at www.ucl.ac.uk.

tracks.title: Plato on Rhetoric v. Philosophy - Partially Examined Life
tracks.description:
On Plato‚Äôs Dialogue, ‚ÄúGorgias‚Äù (380 BCE or so).

Why philosophize? Isn‚Äôt it better to know how to persuade people in practical matters, like a successful lawyer or business leader? Plato (speaking as usual through Socrates) thinks that the ‚Äúart‚Äù of rhetoric (persuasive speeches) isn‚Äôt an art at all, in the sense of something that requires an understanding of one‚Äôs subject matter, but merely a talent for saying what people want to hear. Gorgias (and Socrates‚Äôs other interlocutors) think that being able to persuade gives you power, so it‚Äôs awesome, but Plato thinks that unless what you say is likely to improve your audience, then it‚Äôs worthless. The argument is generalizable to all artistic endeavor: Do the arts aim to just give pleasure, and even if they do, is that bad?
